    • Can we solve

    Techno-Inequality?

    The difference in opportunity between those who have access to technology, and those who do not.

    As with any inequality, technological inequality affects all aspects of life. Your ability to find a job, to receive an education, to change your current socioeconomic situation - they are all intrinsically affected by the technologies you have access to.

    This is especially true for computer, smartphone & internet access.

    A study from 2007 found that "a 10 percentage-point increase in broadband penetration raises annual per-capita growth by 0.9-1.5 percentage points".

    There are many variables for why the internet is a driving force for economic development, but arguably one key aspect is that it is a portal for easily accessible software that allows individuals to automate processes as well as connect with individuals they would otherwise not come in contact with.

    Approaching The Problem

    This project proposes that there are three main causes of techno-inequality:

    1. Access to the internet is limited in parts of the world due to either infrastructure limitations or government policy
    2. Not all individuals can afford a broadband or 3G/4G subscription
    3. Not all individuals can afford the devices required to access the internet.

    While the obvious approach would be to tackle one of these directly, these are very large and complex issues.

    You could campaign for governments to improve internet access, find a way to subsidise internet access, you could donate devices or develop cheaper ones.

    However all of these solutions require time and - more importantly - substantial capital.

    In the absence of time and capital, we still have the ability to affect change via smaller, targeted solutions.

    While not a direct solution to this problem, this project proposes a small solution with the potential to make a sizable impact - a microintervention.

    Instead of focusing on providing the technology itself - why not attempt to provide a more cost-effective solution with the same benefits?

    Mobile Icons made by Freepik

    Older cellphones (not smartphones) are much cheaper devices, and since the technology has been around since 1983 cell tower infrastructure is widely available even in relatively poor countries.

    According to sources only 50% of the world's population having access to 3G or 4G networks, and a measly 9.8% of the world's population has acess to broadband. In comparison, mobile cellular penetration was almost at 100% in 2013.

    Data Sources: Pew Global, World Bank, PCMag, Tech Crunch, Deccan Herald, Wikipedia

    Why not use existing cellphone technology and infrastructure to create useful services that interface with the internet?

    SMaaS: Short Messaging as a Service

    SMaaS is a portmanteau of two terms:

    1. SMS:
      Short Message Service: a system for sending short text messages, as from one cell phone to another or from a computer to a cell phone.
    2. SaaS
      Software as a Service (SaaS) is a software distribution model in which applications are hosted by a vendor or service provider and made available to customers over a network, typically the Internet.

    These kind of services already exist in some parts of the world, for example, MTA Bus Time which allows you to check when buses are arriving at a stop.

    There's also the much hyped Magic which you basically text to have someone act as your virtual assistant

    These wonderful examples were captured by Jonathan Libov in his article about the Futures of Text

    The Tech

    Twilio's SMS services allow you to Programmatically Send, Receive & Track SMS globally from one API.

    The other components of these services will likely have to vary from application to application.

    Have a suggestion about technology that would be useful to build SMaaS projects? Create a pull request with your suggestion

    The Designs

    There are two main challenges of creating a SMS-based interface:

    1. Conciseness
      You must keep any interaction that needs to be in the same message under 160 characters
    2. Instructional
      The user needs to be able to understand how to use your service with very little guidance as the only way for them to learn how to use your service is likely to be in the service itself

    The designs below explore how these limitations affect and inform the user flow

    A Rudimentary Job Board
    Linnea Strid
    March 31, 2015

    Onboarding the user

    In this setup example, let’s assume the user finds/sees an advertisement for the service, which includes the number and the instructions “Text START to Start looking for or listing a job!”

    User
    START
    Service
    Welcome to the Job board!

    To list a job, reply with LISTJOB.

    To look for jobs reply with LOOKFORJOB

    For help, reply with HELP
    131 characters

    Listing a Job

    In an ideal setting, the job board should exist both online and via SMS. This is why the Job listing process is structured in the same way as a form, with the data that will be relevant for searchability grouped in one input.

    The 160 character limit does mean that it is difficult to not break up the process into multiple steps. However, if the user does not need to change anything in their listing, they will “only” send 7 SMS.

    Perhaps the solution would be to allow them to quicklist with one message, however it presents some problems in how the data would be interpreted by the database and could prevent jobseekers from filtering jobs properly.

    User
    LISTJOB
    Service
    This is the first time you are listing a job.

    To start listing, reply with the city the job is in.
    100 characters
    User
    Achenetone
    Service
    You can view and change your answers at any time by replying CHANGE.

    Please tell me the job title & employer name.

    Example: Secretary at Madison Park Hotel
    158 characters
    User
    Junior Mechanic at Johnny Road Speedy Motors
    Service
    What is the hourly salary for this job in dollars?

    Example: 4.50

    68 character
    User
    8
    Service
    What is the minimum years of experience you require the applicant to have?

    Example: 2
    87 characters
    User
    2
    Service
    What phone number should applicants contact to apply?

    Reply MINE to use the number of the phone you are using

    Example: 0729830940
    133 characters
    User
    MINE
    Service
    We are sending you a message with what your job listing will look like.

    To change anything reply with CHANGE. To post your listing, reply CONFIRM.
    148 characters
    Service
    Junior Mechanic at Johnny Road Speedy Motors, Achenetone

    SLRY: $8/HR
    MIN 2YR XP
    DATE ADDED: 07/03/15

    07593874028
    97 characters
    User
    CONFIRM
    Service
    Your Job listing has been posted! Write MYLISTINGS at any time to view your listings.
    85 characters

    Looking for a Job

    The main benefit we try to offer in this user flow is the ability to seek out jobs that are targeted to the users skills and preferences. It focuses on location, job role & salary

    The system should ideally be able to smartmatch keywords even if they are not identical.

    User
    LOOKFORJOB
    Service
    This is the first time you are using the job board

    List the cities or areas you want to work in, separate with commas

    Example: Achenetone, Mochudi, Molepole
    159 characters
    User
    Achenetone, Halifax, Grucho, Chogo, Minuti
    Service
    List the jobs you are looking for, separate with commas

    Example: Engineer, Mechanic, Plumber
    93 characters
    User
    Hairdresser, Beautician, Nails, Beauty, Salon
    Service
    What is the minimum hourly salary you are looking for (in dollars)?

    Example: 5.50
    82 characters
    User
    10
    Service
    Preferences:

    Hairdresser, Beautician, Nails, Beauty, Salon in Achenetone, Halifax, Grucho, Chogo, Minuti

    MIN SLRY: $10/HR

    To change, reply PREF
    149 characters
    Service
    We have found 1 job matching your preferences

    Reply SHOW1, SHOW5, SHOW10 or SHOWALL to view listings (newest first)

    To change preferences, reply PREF
    153 characters
    User
    SHOWALL
    Service
    Junior Beautician at Jenny’s nails in Halifax

    SLRY: $13/HR
    MIN 5YR XP
    DATE ADDED: 01/04/15

    CONTACT: 0208292832420
    118 characters
    Service
    Didn’t find what you’re looking for?

    Reply with SUBSCRIBE to receive messages as soon as matching job listings are posted
    123 characters

    The user flows outlined above are not final, but present a groundwork for interesting SMS services.

    What this project considers the most important is the shift in thinking - that it is possible to translate internet usefullness into the very low-fi interaction of SMS. It only requires the hosting party to have the computational power.

    Contribute

    The SmaaS project is open source and can be found here

    Calling all UX Designers!

    Want to take on the challenge of transforming your favourite SaaS or other online service into a SMS product?

    If you're comfortable with coding fork the repo and create a PR with your design suggestion as a page in the _posts folder. The SMaaS Project uses Jekyll so as long as you can use markdown you can contribute!

    If not, feel free to get in touch with your contribution

    Technical Suggestions

    Got technical advice, or think you can build a product from a design in the SMaaS project? submit a pull request with notes in index.html with your tech advice or contribution or get in touch with your suggestions.

    Want to make any of the ideas in here a reality?

    Go ahead! There is no need to ask or give any credit but I would love to know how it goes.

    Disclaimer: The SMaaS project was developed as a response to Hyper Island's Creative Task 2015
